Analyse a protein sequence (using methods that are only applicable to protein sequences).
Analyse repeat sequence organisation such as periodicity.
Find (and possibly render) short repetitive subsequences (repeat sequences) in (typically nucleotide) sequences.

comment: Repeat sequences include tandem repeats, inverted or palindromic repeats, DNA microsatellites (Simple Sequence Repeats or SSRs), interspersed repeats, maximal duplications and reverse, complemented and reverse complemented repeats etc. Repeat units can be exact or imperfect, in tandem or dispersed, of specified or unspecified length.
children.definition: Find and/or analyse repeat sequences in (typically nucleotide) sequences.

comment: Motifs and patterns might be conserved or over-represented (occur with improbable frequency).
children.definition: Discover new motifs or conserved patterns in sequences or sequence alignments (de-novo discovery).
Find (scan for) known motifs, patterns and regular expressions in molecular sequence(s).

comment: Look at "Protein feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_3092) and "Nucleic acid feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_0415) in case more specific terms are needed.
children.definition: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in molecular sequences such as key functional sites or regions.
Analyse one or more known molecular sequences.

comment: A micrograph can include particles in multiple different orientations and/or conformations. Particles are compared and organised into sets based on their similarity. Typically iterations of classification and alignment and are performed to optimise the final 3D EM map.
children.definition: Compare (align and classify) multiple particle images from a micrograph in order to produce a representative image of the particle.

comment: Single particle analysis is used to improve the information that can be obtained by relatively low resolution techniques, , e.g. an image of a protein or virus from transmission electron microscopy (TEM).
children.definition: An image processing technique that combines and analyze multiple images of a particulate sample, in order to produce an image with clearer features that are more easily interpreted.
Measurement of neurites; projections (axons or dendrites) from the cell body of a neuron, from analysis of neuron images.
Analysis of cell migration images in order to study cell migration, typically in order to study the processes that play a role in the disease progression.
The analysis of a image (typically a digital image) of some type in order to extract information from it.

Retrieve an entry (or part of an entry) from a data resource that matches a supplied query. This might include some primary data and annotation. The query is a data identifier or other indexed term. For example, retrieve a sequence record with the specified accession number, or matching supplied keywords.
Retrieve resources from information systems matching a specific information need.
Identify semantic relations among entities and concepts within a text, using text mining techniques.
Recognise named entities, ontology concepts, tags, events, and dictionary terms within documents.
Extract structured information from unstructured ("free") or semi-structured textual documents.
Process and analyse text (typically scientific literature) to extract information from it.
Processing of diffraction data into a corrected, ordered, and simplified form.
Phase a macromolecular crystal structure, for example by using molecular replacement or experimental phasing methods.
The evaluation of diffraction intensities and integration of diffraction maxima from a diffraction experiment.
Analysis of data from a diffraction experiment.

comment: A micrograph can include particles in multiple different orientations and/or conformations. Particles are compared and organised into sets based on their similarity. Typically iterations of classification and alignment and are performed to optimise the final 3D EM map.
children.definition: Compare (align and classify) multiple particle images from a micrograph in order to produce a representative image of the particle.

comment: Single particle analysis is used to improve the information that can be obtained by relatively low resolution techniques, , e.g. an image of a protein or virus from transmission electron microscopy (TEM).
children.definition: An image processing technique that combines and analyze multiple images of a particulate sample, in order to produce an image with clearer features that are more easily interpreted.
Analyse, simulate or predict protein folding, typically by processing sequence and / or structural data. For example, predict sites of nucleation or stabilisation key to protein folding.
Predict tertiary structure of protein sequence(s) without homologs of known structure.

comment: Methods might require a preliminary C(alpha) trace.
Scaffold selection, scaffold search, epitope grafting and design optimization are stages of backbone modelling done during rational vaccine design.
children.definition: Model protein backbone conformation.
Model loop conformation in protein structures.

comment: Antibody optimisation is to optimize the antibody-interacting surface of the antigen (epitope). Antigen optimisation is to optimize the antigen-interacting surface of the antibody (paratope). Antigen resurfacing is to resurface the antigen by varying the sequence of non-epitope regions.
Methods might use a residue rotamer library.

This includes rotamer likelihood prediction: the prediction of rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure, where output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.
children.definition: Model, analyse or edit amino acid side chain conformation in protein structure, optimize side-chain packing, hydrogen bonding etc.

comment: The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.
children.definition: Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.

comment: This includes methods that predict the folding pathway(s) or non-native structural intermediates of a protein.
children.definition: Predict tertiary structure (backbone and side-chain conformation) of protein sequences.

comment: Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.
children.definition: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
Compare the architecture of two or more protein structures.
Analyse the architecture (spatial arrangement of secondary structure) of protein structure(s).

comment: Includes secondary structure assignment from circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopic data, and from protein coordinate data.
children.definition: Assign secondary structure from protein coordinate or experimental data.

comment: A free cysteine is neither involved in a cysteine bridge, nor functions as a ligand to a metal.
children.definition: Detect free cysteines in a protein structure.
Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.
Detect cysteine bridges (from coordinate data) in a protein structure.
Assign cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein structures.
children.text: Protein cysteine and disulfide bond assignment

children.definition: Assign a protein tertiary structure (3D coordinates), or other aspects of protein structure, from raw experimental data.

comment: This includes conserved substructures and conserved geometry, such as spatial arrangement of secondary structure or protein backbone. Methods might use structure alignment, structural templates, searches for similar electrostatic potential and molecular surface shape, surface-mapping of phylogenetic information etc.
children.definition: Identify or screen for 3D structural motifs in protein structure(s).
Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.
Predict turn structure (for example beta hairpin turns) of protein sequences.
Predict open coils, non-regular secondary structure and intrinsically disordered / unstructured regions of protein sequences.
Predict helical secondary structure of protein sequences.

comment: Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.
children.definition: Predict super-secondary structure of protein sequence(s).

comment: Methods might use amino acid composition, local sequence information, multiple sequence alignments, physicochemical features, estimated energy content, statistical algorithms, hidden Markov models, support vector machines, kernel machines, neural networks etc.
children.definition: Predict secondary structure of protein sequences.
Compare protein secondary structures.
Analyse protein secondary structure data.
Decompose a structure into compact or globular fragments (protein peeling).
Identify structural domains in a protein structure from first principles (for example calculations on structural compactness).

comment: Methods might identify structural neighbors, find structural similarities or define a structural core.
children.definition: Compare protein tertiary structures.

comment: This includes sequence-to-3D-profile alignment methods, which align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment) - methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).

comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.
children.definition: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.
Validate protein geometry, for example bond lengths, bond angles, torsion angles, chiralities, planaraties etc. An example is validation of a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.
Identify poorly packed residues in protein structures.
A method for making numerical assessments about the maximum percent of time that a conformer of a flexible macromolecule can exist and still be compatible with the experimental data.
Detect 'bumps' between residues in a structure, i.e. those with pairs of atoms whose Van der Waals' radii interpenetrate more than a defined distance.

comment: Model validation might involve checks for atomic packing, steric clashes (bumps), volume irregularities, agreement with electron density maps, number of amino acid residues, percentage of residues with missing or bad atoms, irregular Ramachandran Z-scores, irregular Chi-1 / Chi-2 normality scores, RMS-Z score on bonds and angles etc.

The PDB file format has had difficulties, inconsistencies and errors. Corrections can include identifying a meaningful sequence, removal of alternate atoms, correction of nomenclature problems, removal of incomplete residues and spurious waters, addition or removal of water, modelling of missing side chains, optimisation of cysteine bonds, regularisation of bond lengths, bond angles and planarities etc.

This includes methods that calculate poor quality residues. The scoring function to identify poor quality residues may consider residues with bad atoms or atoms with high B-factor, residues in the N- or C-terminal position, adjacent to an unstructured residue, non-canonical residues, glycine and proline (or adjacent to these such residues).
children.definition: Evaluate the quality or correctness a protein three-dimensional model.
Analyse protein structural data.
Compare two or more molecular surfaces.
Identify and remove redudancy from a set of small molecule structures.
Compare nucleic acid tertiary structures.

comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.
children.definition: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.

comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment.
children.definition: Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.

comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.
children.definition: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.

comment: Includes methods that align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments) - including methods that perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.

comment: Methods might identify structural neighbors, find structural similarities or define a structural core.
children.definition: Compare protein tertiary structures.
Search a database of molecular structure and retrieve structures that are similar to a query structure.
Compare two or more molecular tertiary structures.
Model or simulate protein-protein binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.

comment: Virtual screening is widely used for lead identification, lead optimization, and scaffold hopping during drug design and discovery.
children.definition: Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to identify potential drug compounds. It involves searching libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).

comment: Methods aim to predict the position and orientation of a ligand bound to a protein receptor or enzyme.

Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to search libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).
children.definition: Model protein-ligand (for example protein-peptide) binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.

comment: This includes protein-protein interactions, protein-nucleic acid, protein-ligand binding etc. Methods might predict whether the molecules are likely to bind in vivo, their conformation when bound, the strength of the interaction, possible mutations to achieve bonding and so on.
children.definition: Model the structure of a protein in complex with a small molecule or another macromolecule.
Generate some type of structural (3D) profile or template from a structure or structure alignment.
The simulation of molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.

comment: The technique solves the phase problem, i.e. retrieve information concern phases of the structure.
children.definition: A technique used to construct an atomic model of an unknown structure from diffraction data, based upon an atomic model of a known structure, either a related protein or the same protein from a different crystal form.

comment: Rigid body refinement usually follows molecular replacement in the assignment of a structure from diffraction data.
children.definition: A method used to refine a structure by moving the whole molecule or parts of it as a rigid unit, rather than moving individual atoms.
Refine (after evaluation) a model of a molecular structure (typically a protein structure) to reduce steric clashes, volume irregularities etc.
3D visualization of a molecular trajectory.
Render a helical wheel representation of protein secondary structure.
Visualise transmembrane proteins, typically the transmembrane regions within a sequence.
Render a topology diagram of protein secondary structure.

comment: A dot has three coordinates (x,y,z) and (typically) a color.
children.definition: Calculate the positions of dots that are homogeneously distributed over the surface of a molecule.

comment: This includes visualisation of protein secondary structure such as knots, pseudoknots etc. as well as tertiary and quaternary structure.
children.definition: Visualise or render molecular 3D structure, for example a high-quality static picture or animation.

comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.
children.definition: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.

comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment.
children.definition: Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.

comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.
children.definition: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.

comment: Includes methods that align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments) - including methods that perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.

comment: Solvent accessibility might be calculated for the backbone, sidechain and total (backbone plus sidechain).
children.definition: Calculate solvent accessible or buried surface areas in protein or other molecular structures.
Compare two or more molecular surfaces.
Calculate the molecular surface area in proteins and other macromolecules.

comment: A dot has three coordinates (x,y,z) and (typically) a color.
children.definition: Calculate the positions of dots that are homogeneously distributed over the surface of a molecule.
Analyse the surface properties of proteins or other macromolecules, including surface accessible pockets, interior inaccessible cavities etc.

comment: Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.
children.definition: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
Assign molecular structure(s) to a group or category.

comment: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a multivariate statistical analysis to obtain collective variables and reduce the dimensionality of the system.
children.definition: Compute Essential Dynamics (ED) on a simulation trajectory: an analysis of molecule dynamics using PCA (Principal Component Analysis) applied to the atomic positional fluctuations.
Predict DNA tertiary structure.

Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data. For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.
Predict RNA tertiary structure.

comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).
children.definition: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).

comment: Methods might identify thermodynamically stable or evolutionarily conserved structures.
children.definition: Predict structure of DNA or RNA.

Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data. For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.
Compare nucleic acid tertiary structures.
Align RNA secondary structures.
Compute the covariance model for (a family of) RNA secondary structures.

comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).
children.definition: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).
Process (read and / or write) RNA secondary structure data.
Analyse nucleic acid tertiary structural data.
Analyse known molecular tertiary structures.
Calculate a theoretical mass spectrometry spectra for given sequences.
Mass spectra identification of compounds that are produced by living systems. Including polyketides, terpenoids, phenylpropanoids, alkaloids and antibiotics.
Quantification analysis using chemical labeling by stable isotope dimethylation
Chemical tagging free amino groups of intact proteins with stable isotopes.
Quantification analysis using stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture.

comment: This includes N-15 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using N-15 enriched grown medium or feed) and C-13 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 enriched grown medium or feed).
children.definition: Labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 or N-15 enriched grown medium or feed.
Quantification analysis using the Thermo Fisher tandem mass tag labelling workflow.
Quantification analysis using labeling based on 18O-enriched H2O.
Quantification analysis using the AB SCIEX iTRAQ isobaric labelling workflow, wherein 2-8 reporter ions are measured in MS2 spectra near 114 m/z.
Quantification based on the use of chemical tags.
Quantification by Selected/multiple Reaction Monitoring workflow (XIC quantitation of precursor / fragment mass pair).
Calculate number of identified MS2 spectra as approximation of peptide / protein quantity.
Label-free quantification by integration of ion current (ion counting).
Quantification without the use of chemical tags.
Technique for determining the amount of proteins in a sample.
Site localisation of post-translational modifications in peptide or protein mass spectra.
Identification of post-translational modifications (PTMs) of peptides/proteins in mass spectrum.

Statistical estimation of false discovery rate from score distribution for peptide-spectrum-matches, following a peptide database search, and by comparison to search results with a database containing incorrect information.
Peptide database search for identification of known and unknown PTMs looking for mass difference mismatches.
Determination of best matches between MS/MS spectrum and a database of protein or nucleic acid sequences.
Match experimentally measured mass spectrum to a spectrum in a spectral library or database.
Peptide sequence tags are used as piece of information about a peptide obtained by tandem mass spectrometry.
Analytical process that derives a peptide's amino acid sequence from its tandem mass spectrum (MS/MS) without the assistance of a sequence database.
Determination of peptide sequence from mass spectrum.

comment: Deisotoping is commonly done to reduce complexity, and done in conjunction with the charge state deconvolution.
children.definition: The removal of isotope peaks in a spectrum, to represent the fragment ion as one data point.
Align multiple data sets using information from chromatography and/or peptide identification, from mass spectrometry experiments.
Identification of protein, for example from one or more peptide identifications by tandem mass spectrometry.
Re-adjust the output of mass spectrometry experiments with shifted ppm values.
Identify peaks in a spectrum from a mass spectrometry, NMR, or some other spectrum-generating experiment.
Analyse one or more spectra from mass spectrometry (or other) experiments.
The analysis and simulation of disease transmission using, for example, statistical methods such as the SIR-model.
The analysis, using proteomics techniques, to identify proteins whose encoding genes are differentially expressed under a given experimental setup.

comment: Differential gene expression analysis is used, for example, to identify which genes are up-regulated (increased expression) or down-regulated (decreased expression) between a group treated with a drug and a control groups.
children.definition: Identify from molecular sequence analysis (typically from analysis of microarray or RNA-seq data) genes whose expression levels are significantly different between two sample groups.

comment: Gene expression profiling generates some sort of gene expression profile, for example from microarray data.
children.definition: The measurement of the activity (expression) of multiple genes in a cell, tissue, sample etc., in order to get an impression of biological function.
Analyze time series data from an RNA-seq experiment.
Analyze read counts from RNA-seq experiments.
Analyze data from RNA-seq experiments.
Map an expression profile to known biological pathways, for example, to identify or reconstruct a pathway.

Combine classical quantitative trait loci (QTL) analysis with gene expression profiling, for example, to describe describe cis- and trans-controlling elements for the expression of phenotype associated genes.
exact_synonyms: Gene expression quantitative trait loci profiling

children.definition: The analysis of microRNAs (miRNAs) : short, highly conserved small noncoding RNA molecules that are naturally occurring plant and animal genomes.
Perform cluster analysis of expression data to identify groups with similar expression profiles, for example by clustering.
Analyse the correlation patterns among features/molecules across across a variety of experiments, samples etc.
Comparison of expression profiles.
Generate a plot of distances (distance or correlation matrix) between expression values.
Visualise gene expression data after hierarchical clustering for representing hierarchical relationships.

comment: In the case of microarray data, visualise clustered gene expression data as a set of profiles, where each profile shows the gene expression values of a cluster across samples on the X-axis.
children.definition: Visualise clustered quantitative data as set of different profiles, where each profile is plotted versus different entities or samples on the X-axis.

comment: The heat map usually uses a coloring scheme to represent expression values. They can show how quantitative measurements were influenced by experimental conditions.
children.definition: Generate a heat map of expression data from e.g. microarray data.
Visualise clustered expression data using a tree diagram.
exact_synonyms: Expression data tree or dendrogram rendering

children.definition: Visualise microarray or other expression data.
Predict a network of gene regulation.
Analyse a known network of gene regulation.

comment: Analyse gene expression patterns to identify sets of genes that are associated with a specific trait, condition, clinical outcome etc.
Gene sets can be defined beforehand by biological function, chromosome locations and so on.

"Gene set analysis" (often used interchangeably or in an overlapping sense with "gene-set enrichment analysis") refers to the functional analysis (term enrichment) of a differentially expressed set of genes, rather than all genes analysed.
The Gene Ontology (GO) is typically used, the input is a set of Gene IDs, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of GO concepts, each associated with a p-value.
children.definition: Identify classes of genes or proteins that are over or under-represented in a large set of genes or proteins. For example analysis of a set of genes corresponding to a gene expression profile, annotated with Gene Ontology (GO) concepts, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain GO concept within the studied set of genes is revealed.

comment: Metagenomic inference is the profiling of phylogenetic marker genes in order to predict metagenome function.
children.definition: Process (read and/or write) expression data from experiments measuring molecules (e.g. omics data), including analysis of one or more expression profiles, typically to interpret them in functional terms.

comment: This excludes non-analytical methods that read and write the same basic type of data (for that, see 'Data handling').
children.definition: Apply analytical methods to existing data of a specific type.
Refine an existing sequence alignment.

comment: The technique solves the phase problem, i.e. retrieve information concern phases of the structure.

Refine (after evaluation) a model of a molecular structure (typically a protein structure) to reduce steric clashes, volume irregularities etc.
Refine or optimise some data model.

comment: This is typically done to identify possible covarying positions and predict contacts or structural constraints in protein structures.
children.definition: Analyse correlations between sites in a molecular sequence alignment.
Analyse the correlation patterns among features/molecules across across a variety of experiments, samples etc.
Identify a correlation, i.e. a statistical relationship between two random variables or two sets of data.
Design new protein molecules with specific structural or functional properties.
Predict and/or optimize oligonucleotide probes for DNA microarrays, for example for transcription profiling of genes, or for genomes and gene families.
Predict and/or optimize oligonucleotide probes for DNA microarrays, for example for transcription profiling of genes, or for genomes and gene families.

comment: Primer design involves predicting or selecting primers that are specific to a provided PCR template. Primers can be designed with certain properties such as size of product desired, primer size etc. The output might be a minimal or overlapping primer set.

This includes predicting primers based on gene structure, promoters, exon-exon junctions, predicting primers that are conserved across multiple genomes or species, primers for for gene transcription profiling, for genotyping polymorphisms, for example single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), for large scale sequencing, or for methylation PCRs.
children.definition: Design or predict oligonucleotide primers for PCR and DNA amplification etc.
narrow_synonyms: PCR primer design (based on gene structure)
PCR primer design (for gene transcription profiling)
PCR primer design (for large scale sequencing)

children.definition: Predict oligonucleotide primers or probes.
Predict or optimise RNA sequences (sequence pools) with likely secondary and tertiary structure for in vitro selection.
A technique whereby molecules with desired properties and function are isolated from libraries of random molecules, through iterative cycles of selection, amplification, and mutagenesis.
Predict or optimise DNA to elicit (via DNA vaccination) an immunological response.
Design (or predict) nucleic acid sequences with specific chemical or physical properties.

comment: Virtual screening is widely used for lead identification, lead optimization, and scaffold hopping during drug design and discovery.
children.definition: Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to identify potential drug compounds. It involves searching libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).

comment: Small molecule design can involve assessment of target druggability and flexibility, molecular docking, in silico fragment screening, molecular dynamics, and homology modeling.

There are two broad categories of small molecule design techniques when applied to the design of drugs: ligand-based drug design (e.g. ligand similarity) and structure-based drug design (ligand docking) methods. Ligand similarity methods exploit structural similarities to known active ligands, whereas ligand docking methods use the 3D structure of a target protein to predict the binding modes and affinities of ligands to it.
children.definition: The design of small molecules with specific biological activity, such as inhibitors or modulators for proteins that are of therapeutic interest. This can involve the modification of individual atoms, the addition or removal of molecular fragments, and the use reaction-based design to explore tractable synthesis options for the small molecule.
Design a biological entity (typically a molecular sequence or structure) with specific properties.
Identify and filter a (typically large) sequence data set to remove sequences from contaminants in the sample that was sequenced.

comment: For example process paired end reads to trim low quality ends remove short sequences, identify sequence inserts, detect chimeric reads, or remove low quality sequnces including vector, adaptor, low complexity and contaminant sequences. Sequences might come from genomic DNA library, EST libraries, SSH library and so on.
children.definition: Pre-process sequence reads to ensure (or improve) quality and reliability.
Variant filtering is used to eliminate false positive variants based for example on base calling quality, strand and position information, and mapping info.
Evaluate a DNA sequence assembly, typically for purposes of quality control.

comment: Analyse raw sequence data from a sequencing pipeline and identify (and possiby fix) problems.

Apply bootstrapping or other measures to estimate confidence of a phylogenetic tree.

Statistical estimation of false discovery rate from score distribution for peptide-spectrum-matches, following a peptide database search, and by comparison to search results with a database containing incorrect information.

Assign molecular sequences, structures or other biological data to a specific group or category according to qualities it shares with that group or category.
Visualise, format or render sequence clusters.

comment: Comparison of two sets of quantitative data such as two samples of gene expression values.
children.definition: Render a graph in which the values of two variables are plotted along two axes; the pattern of the points reveals any correlation.
Plot a protein titration curve.

comment: In the case of micorarray data, visualise raw and pre-processed gene expression data, via a plot showing over- and under-expression along with mean, upper and lower quartiles.
children.definition: Generate a box plot, i.e. a depiction of groups of numerical data through their quartiles.
Draw a circular maps of DNA, for example a plasmid map.
Draw or visualise restriction maps in DNA sequences.
Visualise operon structure etc.
Draw or visualise a DNA map.

comment: Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.
children.definition: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.
Render and visualise a DNA sequence assembly.
Visualise, format or render a nucleic acid sequence that is part of (and in context of) a complete genome sequence.

comment: Dot plots are useful when having not too many (e.g. 20) data points for each category. Example: draw a dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.
children.definition: Render a representation of a distribution that consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale.
Identify and plot third base position variability in a nucleotide sequence.
Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.
Visualise, format or render a molecular sequence or sequences such as a sequence alignment, possibly with sequence features or properties shown.
Visualise, format or render a mass spectrum.
Plot an incident curve such as a survival curve, death curve, mortality curve.
Visualise, format or render an image of a Chromatogram.
Render (visualise) a biological pathway.
Visualise, format or render data from an ontology, typically a tree of terms.
3D visualization of a molecular trajectory.
Render a helical wheel representation of protein secondary structure.
Visualise transmembrane proteins, typically the transmembrane regions within a sequence.
Render a topology diagram of protein secondary structure.

comment: A dot has three coordinates (x,y,z) and (typically) a color.
children.definition: Calculate the positions of dots that are homogeneously distributed over the surface of a molecule.

comment: This includes visualisation of protein secondary structure such as knots, pseudoknots etc. as well as tertiary and quaternary structure.
children.definition: Visualise or render molecular 3D structure, for example a high-quality static picture or animation.
Render (visualise) a network - typically a biological network of some sort.
Visualise images resulting from various types of microscopy.
Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting curve.
Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA temperature profile.
Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA probability profile.

comment: A stitch profile represents the alternative conformations that partly melted DNA can adopt in a temperature range.
children.definition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA stitch profile.

comment: A melting profile is used to visualise and analyse partly melted DNA conformations.
children.definition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting profile.
Render or visualise a phylogenetic tree.
Generate a plot of distances (distance or correlation matrix) between expression values.
Visualise gene expression data after hierarchical clustering for representing hierarchical relationships.

comment: In the case of microarray data, visualise clustered gene expression data as a set of profiles, where each profile shows the gene expression values of a cluster across samples on the X-axis.
children.definition: Visualise clustered quantitative data as set of different profiles, where each profile is plotted versus different entities or samples on the X-axis.

comment: The heat map usually uses a coloring scheme to represent expression values. They can show how quantitative measurements were influenced by experimental conditions.
children.definition: Generate a heat map of expression data from e.g. microarray data.
Visualise clustered expression data using a tree diagram.
exact_synonyms: Expression data tree or dendrogram rendering

children.definition: Visualise microarray or other expression data.
Visualise, format or render data arising from an analysis of multiple samples from a metagenomics/community experiment.

comment: Examples for visualization are the distribution of variance over the components, loading and score plots.

The use of Principal Component Analysis (PCA), a multivariate statistical analysis to obtain collective variables on the atomic positional fluctuations, helps to separate the configurational space in two subspaces: an essential subspace containing relevant motions, and another one containing irrelevant local fluctuations.
children.definition: Visualize the results of a principal component analysis (orthogonal data transformation). For example, visualization of the principal components (essential subspace) coming from a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on the trajectory atomistic coordinates of a molecular structure.

comment: This includes methods to render and visualise molecules.
children.definition: Visualise, plot or render (graphically) biomolecular data such as molecular sequences or structures.
Analyse, simulate or predict protein folding, typically by processing sequence and / or structural data. For example, predict sites of nucleation or stabilisation key to protein folding.
The development and use of mathematical models and systems analysis for the description of ecological processes, and applications such as the sustainable management of resources.
Simulate gene expression data, e.g. for purposes of benchmarking.
The simulation of molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.

comment: Methods might require a preliminary C(alpha) trace.
Scaffold selection, scaffold search, epitope grafting and design optimization are stages of backbone modelling done during rational vaccine design.
children.definition: Model protein backbone conformation.
Model loop conformation in protein structures.

comment: Antibody optimisation is to optimize the antibody-interacting surface of the antigen (epitope). Antigen optimisation is to optimize the antigen-interacting surface of the antibody (paratope). Antigen resurfacing is to resurface the antigen by varying the sequence of non-epitope regions.
Methods might use a residue rotamer library.

This includes rotamer likelihood prediction: the prediction of rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure, where output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.
children.definition: Model, analyse or edit amino acid side chain conformation in protein structure, optimize side-chain packing, hydrogen bonding etc.

comment: The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.
children.definition: Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.
The analysis and simulation of disease transmission using, for example, statistical methods such as the SIR-model.
Obtain force field parameters (charge, bonds, dihedrals, etc.) from a molecule, to be used in molecular simulations

Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data. For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.
Identify a plausible model of DNA substitution that explains a molecular (DNA or protein) sequence alignment.

comment: Methods might require a pre-mRNA or genomic DNA sequence.
children.definition: Identify, predict or analyse splice sites in nucleotide sequences.
Predict splicing alternatives or transcript isoforms from analysis of sequence data.
Predict, analyse, characterize or model splice sites, splicing events and so on, typically by comparing multiple nucleic acid sequences.
Model or simulate some biological entity or system, typically using mathematical techniques including dynamical systems, statistical models, differential equations, and game theoretic models.
Identify or predict causes for antibiotic resistance from molecular sequence analysis.
The prediction of the degree of pathogenicity of a microorganism from analysis of molecular sequences.
Predict tertiary structure of protein sequence(s) without homologs of known structure.

comment: Methods might require a preliminary C(alpha) trace.
Scaffold selection, scaffold search, epitope grafting and design optimization are stages of backbone modelling done during rational vaccine design.
children.definition: Model protein backbone conformation.
Model loop conformation in protein structures.

comment: Antibody optimisation is to optimize the antibody-interacting surface of the antigen (epitope). Antigen optimisation is to optimize the antigen-interacting surface of the antibody (paratope). Antigen resurfacing is to resurface the antigen by varying the sequence of non-epitope regions.
Methods might use a residue rotamer library.

This includes rotamer likelihood prediction: the prediction of rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure, where output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.
children.definition: Model, analyse or edit amino acid side chain conformation in protein structure, optimize side-chain packing, hydrogen bonding etc.

comment: The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.
children.definition: Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.

comment: This includes methods that predict the folding pathway(s) or non-native structural intermediates of a protein.
children.definition: Predict tertiary structure (backbone and side-chain conformation) of protein sequences.
Identify or predict intrinsically disordered regions in proteins.
Analyse a network of protein interactions.
Predict the interactions of proteins with other proteins.
Predict a network of protein interactions.

comment: Includes analysis of raw experimental protein-protein interaction data from for example yeast two-hybrid analysis, protein microarrays, immunoaffinity chromatography followed by mass spectrometry, phage display etc.
children.definition: Analyse the interactions of proteins with other proteins.
Predict DNA-binding proteins.
Predict RNA-binding proteins.
Analyse the interaction of protein with nucleic acids, e.g. RNA or DNA-binding sites, interfaces etc.
Predict or detect active sites in proteins; the region of an enzyme which binds a substrate bind and catalyses a reaction.
Predict or detect ligand-binding sites in proteins; a region of a protein which reversibly binds a ligand for some biochemical purpose, such as transport or regulation of protein function.
Predict or detect DNA-binding sites in protein sequences.
Predict or detect RNA-binding sites in protein sequences.

comment: This includes methods that predict and optimise zinc finger protein domains for DNA/RNA binding (for example for transcription factors and nucleases).
children.definition: Predict or detect RNA and DNA-binding binding sites in protein sequences.
Predict or detect metal ion-binding sites in proteins.
Identify or predict protein-protein binding sites.
Identify or predict catalytic residues, active sites or other ligand-binding sites in protein sequences or structures.

comment: Immunological system are cellular or humoral. In vaccine design to induces a cellular immune response, methods must search for antigens that can be recognized by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules present in T lymphocytes. If a humoral response is required, antigens for B cells must be identified.
This includes methods that generate a graphical rendering of antigenicity of a protein, such as a Hopp and Woods plot.
This is usually done in the development of peptide-specific antibodies or multi-epitope vaccines. Methods might use sequence data (for example motifs) and / or structural data.
children.definition: Predict antigenicity, allergenicity / immunogenicity, allergic cross-reactivity etc of peptides and proteins.
Model or simulate protein-protein binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.

comment: Virtual screening is widely used for lead identification, lead optimization, and scaffold hopping during drug design and discovery.
children.definition: Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to identify potential drug compounds. It involves searching libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).

comment: Methods aim to predict the position and orientation of a ligand bound to a protein receptor or enzyme.

Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to search libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).
children.definition: Model protein-ligand (for example protein-peptide) binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.

comment: This includes protein-protein interactions, protein-nucleic acid, protein-ligand binding etc. Methods might predict whether the molecules are likely to bind in vivo, their conformation when bound, the strength of the interaction, possible mutations to achieve bonding and so on.
children.definition: Model the structure of a protein in complex with a small molecule or another macromolecule.

comment: The prediction might include subcellular localisation (nuclear, cytoplasmic, mitochondrial, chloroplast, plastid, membrane etc) or export (extracellular proteins) of a protein.
children.definition: Predict the subcellular localisation of a protein sequence.

comment: Methods might use sequence motifs and features, amino acid composition, profiles, machine-learned classifiers, etc.
children.definition: Detect or predict signal peptides and signal peptide cleavage sites in protein sequences.
Compare the functional properties of two or more proteins.

comment: For functional properties that can be mapped to a sequence, use 'Sequence feature detection (protein)' instead.
children.definition: Predict the biological or biochemical role of a protein, or other aspects of a protein function.
Predict DNA tertiary structure.

Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data. For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.
Predict RNA tertiary structure.

comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).
children.definition: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).

comment: Methods might identify thermodynamically stable or evolutionarily conserved structures.
children.definition: Predict structure of DNA or RNA.

comment: Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.
children.definition: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
Predict and/or optimize oligonucleotide probes for DNA microarrays, for example for transcription profiling of genes, or for genomes and gene families.

comment: Primer design involves predicting or selecting primers that are specific to a provided PCR template. Primers can be designed with certain properties such as size of product desired, primer size etc. The output might be a minimal or overlapping primer set.

This includes predicting primers based on gene structure, promoters, exon-exon junctions, predicting primers that are conserved across multiple genomes or species, primers for for gene transcription profiling, for genotyping polymorphisms, for example single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), for large scale sequencing, or for methylation PCRs.
children.definition: Design or predict oligonucleotide primers for PCR and DNA amplification etc.
narrow_synonyms: PCR primer design (based on gene structure)
PCR primer design (for gene transcription profiling)
PCR primer design (for large scale sequencing)

children.definition: Predict oligonucleotide primers or probes.

comment: Chip-sequencing combines chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) with massively parallel DNA sequencing to generate a set of reads, which are aligned to a genome sequence. The enriched areas contain the binding sites of DNA-associated proteins. For example, a transcription factor binding site. ChIP-on-chip in contrast combines chromatin immunoprecipitation ('ChIP') with microarray ('chip'). "Peak-pair calling" is similar to "Peak calling" in the context of ChIP-exo.
children.definition: Identify putative protein-binding regions in a genome sequence from analysis of Chip-sequencing data or ChIP-on-chip data.

comment: An isochore is long region (> 3 KB) of DNA with very uniform GC content, in contrast to the rest of the genome. Isochores tend tends to have more genes, higher local melting or denaturation temperatures, and different flexibility. Methods might calculate fractional GC content or variation of GC content, predict methylation status of CpG islands etc. This includes methods that visualise CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence, for example plot isochores in a genome sequence.
children.definition: Find CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence or isochores in genome sequences.
Identify or predict nucleosome exclusion sequences (nucleosome free regions) in DNA.
Detect or predict transposons, retrotransposons / retrotransposition signatures etc.
Detect vector sequences in nucleotide sequence, typically by comparison to a set of known vector sequences.

comment: Quadruplex (4-stranded) structures are formed by guanine-rich regions and are implicated in various important biological processes and as therapeutic targets.
children.definition: Detect quadruplex-forming motifs in nucleotide sequences.
Find and identify restriction enzyme cleavage sites (restriction sites) in (typically) DNA sequences, for example to generate a restriction map.
Identify binding sites in nucleic acid sequences that are statistically significantly differentially bound between sample groups.
Find (and possibly render) short repetitive subsequences (repeat sequences) in (typically nucleotide) sequences.
The prediction of DNA modifications (e.g. N4-methylcytosine and N6-Methyladenine) using, for example, statistical models.
Detect polyA signals in nucleotide sequences.

comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).
children.definition: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).

comment: Methods typically involve scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.

This is placeholder but does not comprehensively include all child concepts - please inspect other concepts under "Nucleic acid sequence analysis" for example "Gene prediction", for other feature detection operations.
children.definition: Predict, recognise and identify features in nucleotide sequences such as functional sites or regions, typically by scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.
Predict the structure of a multi-subunit protein and particularly how the subunits fit together.
The simulation of molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.

comment: Includes secondary structure assignment from circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopic data, and from protein coordinate data.
children.definition: Assign secondary structure from protein coordinate or experimental data.

comment: A free cysteine is neither involved in a cysteine bridge, nor functions as a ligand to a metal.
children.definition: Detect free cysteines in a protein structure.
Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.
Detect cysteine bridges (from coordinate data) in a protein structure.
Assign cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein structures.
children.text: Protein cysteine and disulfide bond assignment

children.definition: Assign a protein tertiary structure (3D coordinates), or other aspects of protein structure, from raw experimental data.
Identification of protein, for example from one or more peptide identifications by tandem mass spectrometry.

Retrieve an entry (or part of an entry) from a data resource that matches a supplied query. This might include some primary data and annotation. The query is a data identifier or other indexed term. For example, retrieve a sequence record with the specified accession number, or matching supplied keywords.
Retrieve resources from information systems matching a specific information need.
Identify semantic relations among entities and concepts within a text, using text mining techniques.
Recognise named entities, ontology concepts, tags, events, and dictionary terms within documents.
Extract structured information from unstructured ("free") or semi-structured textual documents.
Process and analyse text (typically scientific literature) to extract information from it.
Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.
Predict turn structure (for example beta hairpin turns) of protein sequences.
Predict open coils, non-regular secondary structure and intrinsically disordered / unstructured regions of protein sequences.
Predict helical secondary structure of protein sequences.

comment: Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.
children.definition: Predict super-secondary structure of protein sequence(s).

comment: Methods might use amino acid composition, local sequence information, multiple sequence alignments, physicochemical features, estimated energy content, statistical algorithms, hidden Markov models, support vector machines, kernel machines, neural networks etc.
children.definition: Predict secondary structure of protein sequences.
Predict genetic code from analysis of codon usage data.

comment: Protein SNP mapping maps and modesl the effects of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on protein structure(s). Methods might predict silent or pathological mutations.
children.definition: Predict the effect of point mutation on a protein structure, in terms of strucural effects and protein folding, stability and function.
Calculate the molecular weight of a protein (or fragments) and compare it to another protein or reference data. Generally used for protein identification.
Calculate the molecular weight of a protein sequence or fragments.
Calculate a theoretical mass spectrometry spectra for given sequences.
Calculate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.
Calculate, visualise or analyse phi/psi angles of a protein structure.
Calculate whether a protein structure has an unusually large net charge (dipole moment).
Calculate Km, Vmax and derived data for an enzyme reaction.
Calculate a residue contact map (typically all-versus-all inter-residue contacts) for a protein structure.
Calculate a matrix of distance between residues (for example the C-alpha atoms) in a protein structure.

comment: This includes for example clusters of hydrophobic or charged residues, or clusters of contacting residues which have a key structural or functional role.
children.definition: Calculate clusters of contacting residues in protein structures.

comment: This includes identifying HET groups, which usually correspond to ligands, lipids, but might also (not consistently) include groups that are attached to amino acids. Each HET group is supposed to have a unique three letter code and a unique name which might be given in the output. It can also include calculation of symmetry contacts, i.e. a contact between two atoms in different asymmetric unit.
children.definition: Calculate contacts between residues, or between residues and other groups, in a protein structure, on the basis of distance calculations.

comment: Salt bridges are interactions between oppositely charged atoms in different residues. The output might include the inter-atomic distance.
children.definition: Calculate (and possibly score) salt bridges in a protein structure.
Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.

comment: The output might include the atoms involved in the bond, bond geometric parameters and bond enthalpy.
children.definition: Identify potential hydrogen bonds between amino acids and other groups.
Calculate protein residue contacts with metal in a structure.
Calculate or extract inter-atomic, inter-residue or residue-atom contacts, distances and interactions in protein structure(s).

comment: Immunological system are cellular or humoral. In vaccine design to induces a cellular immune response, methods must search for antigens that can be recognized by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules present in T lymphocytes. If a humoral response is required, antigens for B cells must be identified.
This includes methods that generate a graphical rendering of antigenicity of a protein, such as a Hopp and Woods plot.
This is usually done in the development of peptide-specific antibodies or multi-epitope vaccines. Methods might use sequence data (for example motifs) and / or structural data.
children.definition: Predict antigenicity, allergenicity / immunogenicity, allergic cross-reactivity etc of peptides and proteins.

comment: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a multivariate statistical analysis to obtain collective variables and reduce the dimensionality of the system.
children.definition: Compute Essential Dynamics (ED) on a simulation trajectory: an analysis of molecule dynamics using PCA (Principal Component Analysis) applied to the atomic positional fluctuations.

comment: Use this concept for analysis of flexible and rigid residues, local chain deformability, regions undergoing conformational change, molecular vibrations or fluctuational dynamics, domain motions or other large-scale structural transitions in a protein structure.
children.definition: Analyse flexibility and motion in protein structure.
Predict extinction coefficients or optical density of a protein sequence.
Predict the solubility or atomic solvation energy of a protein sequence.
Predict the stability or globularity of a protein sequence, whether it is intrinsically unfolded etc.
Calculate aliphatic index (relative volume occupied by aliphatic side chains) of a protein.

comment: Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.
children.definition: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.
Predict crystallizability of a protein sequence.
Calculate hydrophobic or hydrophilic / charged regions of a protein sequence.
Analyse the hydrophobic, hydrophilic or charge properties of a protein (from analysis of sequence or structural information).

comment: A 3D-1D scoring matrix scores the probability of amino acids occurring in different structural environments.
children.definition: Calculate a 3D-1D scoring matrix from analysis of protein sequence and structural data.
Plot a protein titration curve.
Calculate isoelectric point of a protein sequence.
Estimate hydrogen exchange rate of a protein sequence.
Calculate pH-dependent properties from pKa calculations of a protein sequence.

comment: Methods usually involve multiple sequence alignment analysis.
children.definition: Predict contacts, non-covalent interactions and distance (constraints) between amino acids in protein sequences.

comment: This includes methods to render and visualise the properties of a protein sequence, and a residue-level search for properties such as solvent accessibility, hydropathy, secondary structure, ligand-binding etc.
children.definition: Extract, calculate or predict non-positional (physical or chemical) properties of a protein, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence, from processing a protein sequence or 3D structure.

comment: Motifs and patterns might be conserved or over-represented (occur with improbable frequency).
children.definition: Discover new motifs or conserved patterns in sequences or sequence alignments (de-novo discovery).
Find (scan for) known motifs, patterns and regular expressions in molecular sequence(s).

comment: Look at "Protein feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_3092) and "Nucleic acid feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_0415) in case more specific terms are needed.
children.definition: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in molecular sequences such as key functional sites or regions.

comment: An adhesin is a cell-surface component that facilitate the adherence of a microorganism to a cell or surface. They are important virulence factors during establishment of infection and thus are targetted during vaccine development approaches that seek to block adhesin function and prevent adherence to host cell.
children.definition: Predict adhesins in protein sequences.
Identify or predict intrinsically disordered regions in proteins.

comment: Epitope mapping is commonly done during vaccine design.
children.definition: Predict antigenic determinant sites (epitopes) in protein sequences.
Predict or detect active sites in proteins; the region of an enzyme which binds a substrate bind and catalyses a reaction.
Predict or detect ligand-binding sites in proteins; a region of a protein which reversibly binds a ligand for some biochemical purpose, such as transport or regulation of protein function.
Predict or detect DNA-binding sites in protein sequences.
Predict or detect RNA-binding sites in protein sequences.

comment: This includes methods that predict and optimise zinc finger protein domains for DNA/RNA binding (for example for transcription factors and nucleases).
children.definition: Predict or detect RNA and DNA-binding binding sites in protein sequences.
Predict or detect metal ion-binding sites in proteins.
Identify or predict protein-protein binding sites.
Identify or predict catalytic residues, active sites or other ligand-binding sites in protein sequences or structures.
Predict cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein sequences.

comment: This includes conserved substructures and conserved geometry, such as spatial arrangement of secondary structure or protein backbone. Methods might use structure alignment, structural templates, searches for similar electrostatic potential and molecular surface shape, surface-mapping of phylogenetic information etc.
children.definition: Identify or screen for 3D structural motifs in protein structure(s).
Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.
Predict turn structure (for example beta hairpin turns) of protein sequences.
Predict open coils, non-regular secondary structure and intrinsically disordered / unstructured regions of protein sequences.
Predict helical secondary structure of protein sequences.

comment: Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.
children.definition: Predict super-secondary structure of protein sequence(s).

comment: Methods might use amino acid composition, local sequence information, multiple sequence alignments, physicochemical features, estimated energy content, statistical algorithms, hidden Markov models, support vector machines, kernel machines, neural networks etc.
children.definition: Predict secondary structure of protein sequences.

comment: Methods might predict sites of methylation, N-terminal myristoylation, N-terminal acetylation, sumoylation, palmitoylation, phosphorylation, sulfation, glycosylation, glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) modification sites (GPI lipid anchor signals) etc.
children.definition: Predict post-translation modification sites in protein sequences.
Decompose a structure into compact or globular fragments (protein peeling).
Identify structural domains in a protein structure from first principles (for example calculations on structural compactness).

comment: Methods might use sequence motifs and features, amino acid composition, profiles, machine-learned classifiers, etc.
children.definition: Detect or predict signal peptides and signal peptide cleavage sites in protein sequences.
Detect or predict cleavage sites (enzymatic or chemical) in protein sequences.

comment: This includes sequence-to-3D-profile alignment methods, which align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment) - methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).

comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.
children.definition: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.

comment: Features includes functional sites or regions, secondary structure, structural domains and so on. Methods might use fingerprints, motifs, profiles, hidden Markov models, sequence alignment etc to provide a mapping of a query protein sequence to a discriminatory element. This includes methods that search a secondary protein database (Prosite, Blocks, ProDom, Prints, Pfam etc.) to assign a protein sequence(s) to a known protein family or group.
children.definition: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in proteins from analysing protein sequences or structures.
Predict a network of gene regulation.
Predict a metabolic pathway.

comment: Methods might require a pre-mRNA or genomic DNA sequence.
children.definition: Identify, predict or analyse splice sites in nucleotide sequences.
Predict splicing alternatives or transcript isoforms from analysis of sequence data.
Predict, analyse, characterize or model splice sites, splicing events and so on, typically by comparing multiple nucleic acid sequences.
Predict, recognise, detect or identify some properties of a biomolecule.

comment: Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align exactly two molecular sequences.

comment: This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.
children.definition: Align multiple sequences using relative gap costs calculated from neighbors in a supplied phylogenetic tree.
exact_synonyms: Phylogenetic tree-based multiple sequence alignment construction

comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.
children.definition: Align more than two molecular sequences.
Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.

comment: A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles. A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.

comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.
children.definition: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.

comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.
children.definition: Globally align two or more molecular sequences.
Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.

comment: Includes methods that align sequence profiles (representing sequence alignments): ethods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons. See also 'Sequence alignment comparison'.
See also "Read mapping"
children.definition: Align (identify equivalent sites within) molecular sequences.

comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.
children.definition: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.

comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment.
children.definition: Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.

comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.
children.definition: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.

comment: Includes methods that align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments) - including methods that perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.

comment: This includes sequence-to-3D-profile alignment methods, which align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment) - methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).

comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.
children.definition: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.
Compare two or more entities, typically the sequence or structure (or derivatives) of macromolecules, to identify equivalent subunits.
Map an expression profile to known biological pathways, for example, to identify or reconstruct a pathway.

comment: An adhesin is a cell-surface component that facilitate the adherence of a microorganism to a cell or surface. They are important virulence factors during establishment of infection and thus are targetted during vaccine development approaches that seek to block adhesin function and prevent adherence to host cell.
children.definition: Predict adhesins in protein sequences.

comment: Epitope mapping is commonly done during vaccine design.
children.definition: Predict antigenic determinant sites (epitopes) in protein sequences.

comment: The mapping can be achieved by comparing identifier values or some other means, e.g. exact matches to a provided sequence.
children.definition: Map data identifiers to one another for example to establish a link between two biological databases for the purposes of data integration.

comment: Sequence tag mapping assigns experimentally obtained sequence tags to known transcripts or annotate potential virtual sequence tags in a genome.
children.definition: Make sequence tag to gene assignments (tag mapping) of SAGE, MPSS and SBS data.

comment: Haplotype inference can help in population genetic studies and the identification of complex disease genes, , and is typically based on aligned single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) fragments. Haplotype comparison is a useful way to characterize the genetic variation between individuals. An individual's haplotype describes which nucleotide base occurs at each position for a set of common SNPs. Tools might use combinatorial functions (for example parsimony) or a likelihood function or model with optimisation such as minimum error correction (MEC) model, expectation-maximisation algorithm (EM), genetic algorithm or Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC).
children.definition: Infer haplotypes, either alleles at multiple loci that are transmitted together on the same chromosome, or a set of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on a single chromatid that are statistically associated.

comment: Mapping involves ordering genetic loci along a chromosome and estimating the physical distance between loci. A genetic map shows the relative (not physical) position of known genes and genetic markers.
This includes mapping of the genetic architecture of dynamic complex traits (functional mapping), e.g. by characterisation of the underlying quantitative trait loci (QTLs) or nucleotides (QTNs).
children.definition: Generate a genetic (linkage) map of a DNA sequence (typically a chromosome) showing the relative positions of genetic markers based on estimation of non-physical distances.
A varient of oligonucleotide mapping where a read is mapped to two separate locations because of possible structural variation.

comment: The purpose of read mapping is to identify the location of sequenced fragments within a reference genome and assumes that there is, in fact, at least local similarity between the fragment and reference sequences.
children.definition: Align short oligonucleotide sequences (reads) to a larger (genomic) sequence.

comment: Bisulfite mapping follows high-throughput sequencing of DNA which has undergone bisulfite treatment followed by PCR amplification; unmethylated cytosines are specifically converted to thymine, allowing the methylation status of cytosine in the DNA to be detected.
children.definition: The mapping of methylation sites in a DNA (genome) sequence. Typically, the mapping of high-throughput bisulfite reads to the reference genome.
Generate a physical (radiation hybrid) map of genetic markers in a DNA sequence using provided radiation hybrid (RH) scores for one or more markers.

comment: An STS is a short subsequence of known sequence and location that occurs only once in the chromosome or genome that is being mapped. Sources of STSs include 1. expressed sequence tags (ESTs), simple sequence length polymorphisms (SSLPs), and random genomic sequences from cloned genomic DNA or database sequences.
children.definition: Generate a physical DNA map (sequence map) from analysis of sequence tagged sites (STS).

Generate a physical (sequence) map of a DNA sequence showing the physical distance (base pairs) between features or landmarks such as restriction sites, cloned DNA fragments, genes and other genetic markers.
Generate a map of a DNA sequence annotated with positional or non-positional features of some type.
Compare the models or schemas used by two or more databases, or any other general comparison of databases rather than a detailed comparison of the entries themselves.
Map properties to positions on an biological entity (typically a molecular sequence or structure), or assemble such an entity from constituent parts.
Perform cluster analysis of expression data to identify groups with similar expression profiles, for example by clustering.
Build clusters of similar structures, typically using scores from structural alignment methods.
Cluster (group) documents on the basis of their calculated similarity.
Clustering of molecular sequences on the basis of their function, typically using information from an ontology of gene function, or some other measure of functional phenotype.

comment: The clusters may be output or used internally for some other purpose.
children.definition: Build clusters of similar sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.
Group together some data entities on the basis of similarities such that entities in the same group (cluster) are more similar to each other than to those in other groups (clusters).

comment: Many sequence alignment tasks involving many or very large sequences rely on a precomputed index of the sequence to accelerate the alignment. The Burrows-Wheeler Transform (BWT) is a permutation of the genome based on a suffix array algorithm. A suffix array consists of the lexicographically sorted list of suffixes of a genome.
children.definition: Generate an index of a genome sequence.
Generate an index of (typically a file of) biological data.
Calculate the isotope distribution of a given chemical species.
The calculation of species richness for a number of individual samples, based on plots of the number of species as a function of the number of samples (rarefaction curves).
